Signs_and_symptoms: Blood infection: Fever chills vomiting confusionUrinary tract infection: bloody urine cloudy urinePneumonia: Fever chills coughing

high fever that lasts 4 to 6 dayspharyngitis (sore throat)conjunctivitis (inflamed eyes usually without pus formation like pink eye)enlargement of the lymph nodes of the neckheadache malaise and weaknessIncubation period of 5 to 9 days
Diagnosis: Antigen detection polymerase chain reaction assay virus isolation and serology
Treatment: Most infections are mild and require no therapy or only symptomatic treatment.

Signs_and_symptoms: Hemolymphatic phase: Fever lymphadenopathyNeurological phase: Sleep disorders neurological symptoms psychiatric symptoms
Diagnosis: Identification of trypanosomes in a sample by microscopic examination
Treatment: Fexinidazole by mouth or pentamidine by injection for T. b. gambiense.Suramin by injection is used for T. b. rhodesiense

Diagnosis: Antibody test p24 antigen test PCR
Treatment: Treatment is typically a non-nucleoside reverse transcriptase inhibitor (NNRTI) plus two nucleoside analog reverse transcriptase inhibitors (NRTIs)
Those with symptoms require treatment with an amoebicidal tissue-active agent and a luminal cysticidal agent. Individuals that are asymptomatic only need a luminal cysticidal agent.

Signs_and_symptoms: Fever leukopenia abnormally elevated levels of liver enzymes
Diagnosis: indirect immunofluorescence antibody assay for IgG
Treatment: Tetracycline drugs (including tetracycline chlortetracycline oxytetracycline rolitetracycline doxycycline and minocycline) and imidocarb

Signs_and_symptoms: Abdominal pain nausea vomiting and weakness fever central nervous system (CNS) symptoms
Severe abdominal pain malnutrition and vomiting
boil-like skin lesion that eventually forms an ulcer with a black center (eschar)
Treatment: Large doses of intravenous and oral antibiotics such as fluoroquinolones (ciprofloxacin) doxycycline erythromycin vancomycin or penicillin

Signs_and_symptoms: Head and neck infections pharyngitis and sinusitis
Diagnosis: Culture in human blood agar plates
Treatment: erythromycin (proposed as the first-line drug) clindamycin gentamicin and cephalosporins

Signs_and_symptoms: Migrating larvae intestinal blockage and bowel obstruction
Treatment: Albendazole mebendazole levamisole and pyrantel pamoate

Diagnosis: Chest X-ray and CT  microscopy by silver stains
Treatment: Voriconazole and liposomal amphotericin B in combination with surgical debridement

Signs_and_symptoms: Diarrhoea followed by nausea vomiting fever malaise and abdominal pain
Diagnosis: Electron microscopy enzyme-immunoassay (ELISA) immunofluorescence and polymerase chain reaction

Treatment: Atovaquone and azithromycin. In life-threatening cases exchange transfusion is performed.

Signs_and_symptoms: neck stiffness sudden high fever and altered mental status
Diagnosis: Lumbar puncture (contraindicated if there is a mass in the brain or the intracranial pressure is elevated) CT or MRI

Signs_and_symptoms: Fever rigors cough and runny nose chest pain
Diagnosis: Sputum Gram stain and culture Chest radiography

Signs_and_symptoms: Increased vaginal discharge that usually smells like fish
Intermittent diarrhea constipation vomiting abdominal pain anorexia weight loss headache colitis and marked fluid loss
Diagnosis: microscopic examination of stools or colonoscopy or sigmoidoscopy

Signs_and_symptoms: Carrion's disease trench fever cat-scratch disease bacillary angiomatosis peliosis hepatis chronic bacteremia endocarditis chronic lymphadenopathy and neurological disorders
formation of nodules on the scalp moustache and pubic hair
Treatment: Antifungal shampoos such as pyrithione zinc formaldehyde and salicylic acid

Signs_and_symptoms: abdominal pain itching usually anal itching constipation diarrhea watery or loose stool
Diagnosis: microscopic examination of a chemically preserved stool specimen
Treatment: Lack of scientific study to support the efficacy of any particular treatment

Signs_and_symptoms: fever chills arthralgia (joint pain) myalgia (muscle pain) headache and a nonproductive cough
Double vision drooping of both eyelids loss of facial expression and swallowing problems
fevers sweating (often with characteristic foul moldy smell sometimes likened to wet hay) and migratory arthralgia and myalgia (joint and muscle pain)
Treatment: Tetracyclines rifampicin and the aminoglycosides streptomycin and gentamicin

Signs_and_symptoms: Chills malaise high fever muscle cramps seizures
Treatment: Aminoglycosides such as streptomycin and gentamicin tetracyclines (especially doxycycline) and the fluoroquinolone ciprofloxacin
The most widely used antibiotic regimen is once daily oral rifampicin plus twice daily oral clarithromycin.

Signs_and_symptoms: Fever headache and myalgia followed by diarrhea
Treatment: Erythromycin can be used in children and tetracycline in adults.

Diagnosis: In oral candidiasis simply inspecting the person's mouth for white patches and irritation may make the diagnosis.Symptoms of vaginal candidiasis are vaginal itching or soreness pain during sexual intercourse

Signs_and_symptoms: Tooth pain difficulty eating discoloration tooth loss
Fever pale appearance malaise painless liver enlargement jaundice enlarged lymph nodes and enlarged spleen
Diagnosis: Peripheral blood smear with Giemsa stain Columbia blood agar cultures immunoblot indirect immunofluorescence and PCR
Treatment: Fluoroquinolones (such as ciprofloxacin) or chloramphenicol in adults and chloramphenicol plus beta-lactams in children are the antibiotic regimens of choice during the acute phase of Carrion's disease.

Signs_and_symptoms: An area that is red hot and painful
Treatment: Penicillinase-resistant semisynthetic penicillin or a first-generation cephalosporin

Signs_and_symptoms: Fever malaise headache and enlargement of the liver spleen and lymph nodes
Diagnosis: Microscopic examination of fresh anticoagulated blood or its buffy coat for motile parasites; or by preparation of thin and thick blood smears stained with Giemsa for direct visualization of parasites
Treatment: Benznidazole and nifurtimox (though benznidazole is the only drug available in most of Latin America)

The CDC recommendation is either a single oral dose (1 gram) of azithromycin a single IM dose (250mg) of ceftriaxone oral (500mg) of erythromycin three times a day for seven days or oral (500mg) of ciprofloxacin twice a day for three days.

Signs_and_symptoms: nausea loss of appetite aching muscles and headache followed by the characteristic rash or oral sores malaise and a low-grade fever
Diagnosis: The diagnosis of chickenpox is primarily based on the signs and symptoms with typical early symptoms followed by a characteristic rash. Confirmation of the diagnosis is by examination of the fluid within the vesicles of the rash or by testing blood for evidence of an acute immunologic response.

Signs_and_symptoms: sudden onset combining high fever joint pain and rash
Diagnosis: Laboratory criteria include a decreased lymphocyte count consistent with viremia. However a definitive laboratory diagnosis can be accomplished through viral isolation RT-PCR or serological diagnosis.

Signs_and_symptoms: In women those who have an asymptomatic infection that is not detected by their doctor approximately half will develop pelvic inflammatory disease (PID)In men painful or burning sensation when urinating
Diagnosis: Nucleic acid amplification tests (NAAT) such as polymerase chain reaction (PCR) transcription mediated amplification (TMA) and the DNA strand displacement amplification (SDA)
Treatment: azithromycin doxycycline erythromycin levofloxacin or ofloxacin

Disease_name: Chlamydophila pneumoniae infection (Taiwan acute respiratory agent or TWAR)

Signs_and_symptoms: Profuse diarrhea and vomiting of clear fluid
Diagnosis: A rapid dipstick test is available.

Signs_and_symptoms: Usually the infection slowly spreads to the surrounding tissue while still remaining localized to the area around the original wound.
Treatment: Itraconazole an antifungal azole is given orally with or without flucytosine.

Signs_and_symptoms: diarrhea recent antibiotic exposure abdominal pain fever and a distinctive foul odor
Diagnosis: Colonoscopy or sigmoidoscopy cytotoxicity assay toxin ELISA

Disease_name: Common cold (Acute viral rhinopharyngitis Acute coryza)
Signs_and_symptoms: Cough runny nose sneezing nasal congestion and a sore throa
Fever cough loss of taste and smell
Fever headache sore throat gastrointestinal distress extreme fatigue as well as chest and muscle pain
Diagnosis: Enterovirus infection is diagnosed mainly via serological tests such as ELISA and from cell culture.
Treatment: There is no well-accepted treatment for the Coxsackie B group of viruses.

Signs_and_symptoms: Memory loss behavioral changes poor coordination
Cough shortness of breath chest pain and fever
Diagnosis: India ink of the cerebrospinal fluid (CSF)
Treatment: Intravenous Amphotericin B combined with flucytosine by mouth

Signs_and_symptoms: Fatigue swollen glands fever sore throat muscle aches
Sudden-onset fever headache muscle and joint pains and a rash

fever of 38 degrees C (100.4 degrees F) or above; chills; fatigue; bluish skin coloration (cyanosis); sore throat; hoarseness; cough; headache; difficulty swallowing; painful swallowing; difficulty breathing; rapid breathing; foul-smelling and bloodstained nasal discharge; and lymphadenopathy
Diagnosis: Laboratory criteriaIsolation of C. diphtheriae cultureHistopathologic diagnosisToxin demonstrationIn vivo tests (guinea pig inoculation)In vitro test: Elek's gel precipitation test PCR ELISA ICAClinical criteriaURT illness with sore throatLow-grade feverAn adherent dense grey pseudomembrane covering the posterior aspect of the pharynx

Signs_and_symptoms: Burning pain blister from which worm emerges
High fever muscle pain altered mental status headache meningeal irritation photophobia and seizures
Treatment: Corticosteroids anticonvulsants and supportive measures (treating symptoms)

Signs_and_symptoms: Flu-like symptoms severe internal and external bleeding

Treatment: Surgical removal of the cysts combined with chemotherapy

Signs_and_symptoms: Anal itching that gets worse at night disturbed sleep
Severe insomnia followed by dementia hallucinations and death
Discoloration large black blisters foul odor pain and numbness
Symptoms vary from none to severe diarrhea with poor absorption of nutrients.
Diagnosis: Detection of antigens on the surface of organisms in stool
Treatment: Treatment is not always necessary. If medications are needed a nitroimidazole medication is used such as metronidazole tinidazole secnidazole or ornidazole.

Signs_and_symptoms: Swelling itching pain and the formation of pus
Treatment: Ceftriaxone by injection and azithromycin by mouth

Signs_and_symptoms: impetigo cellulitis and erysipelas  to  infections of the skin which can be complicated by necrotizing fasciitis  to  skin fascia and musclestrep throat AKA strep pharyngitis  to  pharynx

Pneumonia: fever lung consolidation pleural effusion tachypnea tachycardia or hypotensionMeningitis: fever confusion hypotension headache nuchal rigidity or changing mental statusBacteremia: fever murmur evidence of an embolic event hypotension phlebitis tachycardia tachypnea splenomegaly or evidence of heart failureSkin and soft tissue infection osteomyelitis septic arthritis or discitis: fever cellulitis arthritis arthralgia localized pain decubitus ulcer vascular insufficiency of the lower extremity back pain wound infection or neurologic dysfunctionUrinary tract infection or pelvic abscess: fever flank pain pelvic pain or abdominal pain

Treatment: In severe cases cefotaxime and ceftriaxone delivered directly into the bloodstream are the elected antibiotics and for the less severe cases an association of ampicillin and sulbactam cephalosporins of the second and third generation or fluoroquinolones are preferred.

Diagnosis: A diagnosis usually can be made by the presenting signs and symptoms alone. If the diagnosis is unclear a throat swab or stool specimen may be taken to identify the virus by culture.
Treatment: Medications are usually not needed as hand foot and mouth disease is a viral disease that typically resolves on its own. Currently there is no specific curative treatment for hand foot and mouth disease.

Signs_and_symptoms: thrombocytopenia and microangiopathic hemolysis plus one or more of the following: neurological symptoms (e.g. confusion cerebral convulsions seizures); renal impairment (e.g. elevated creatinine decreased estimated glomerular filtration rate [eGFR] abnormal urinalysis); and gastrointestinal (GI) symptoms (e.g. diarrhea nausea/vomiting abdominal pain gastroenteritis).
Diagnosis: First diagnosis of aHUS is often made in the context of an initial complement-triggering infection and Shiga-toxin has also been implicated as a trigger that identifies patients with aHUS.
Treatment: Treatment involves supportive care and may include dialysis steroids blood transfusions and plasmapheresis.

Signs_and_symptoms: Redness of cheeks and nose fever chills sweaty palms diarrhea malaise headaches nausea abdominal and back pain respiratory problems
Diagnosis: HFRS is difficult to diagnose on clinical grounds alone and serological evidence is often needed.
Treatment: There is no cure for HFRS. Treatment involves supportive therapy including renal dialysis.

Signs_and_symptoms: Nausea vomiting diarrhea dark urine jaundice fever abdominal pain
None yellowish skin tiredness dark urine abdominal pain

Diagnosis: Blood testing for antibodies or viral RNA
Based on symptoms PCR  viral culture

Signs_and_symptoms: Nonspecific respiratory symptoms often cough or flu-like
Diagnosis: Histoplasmosis can be diagnosed by samples containing the fungus taken from sputum (via bronchoalveolar lavage) blood or infected organs.  It can also be diagnosed by detection of antigens in blood or urine samples by ELISA or polymerase chain reaction.
Treatment: In the majority of immunocompetent individuals histoplasmosis resolves without any treatment. Antifungal medications are used to treat severe cases of acute histoplasmosis and all cases of chronic and disseminated disease. Typical treatment of severe disease first involves treatment with amphotericin B followed by oral itraconazole.

Diagnosis: The diagnosis can be confirmed by using PCR. A peripheral blood smear can also be examined for intracytoplasmic inclusions called morulae.

Signs_and_symptoms: feversevere headachemuscle aches (myalgia)chills and shaking similar to the symptoms of influenzanauseavomitingloss of appetiteunintentional weight lossabdominal paincough
Fever headache malaise and muscle aches (myalgia).
Abdominal pain loss of appetite itching around the anus irritability and diarrhea
Diagnosis: Examination of the stool for eggs and parasites

Signs_and_symptoms: Fever  to  usually lasting 14 days; often mildSore throat  to  usually severe for 3 to 5 days before resolving in the next 7 to 10 days.Swollen glands  to  mobile; usually located around the back of the neck (posterior cervical lymph nodes) and sometimes throughout the body.
Diagnosis: Diagnostic modalities for infectious mononucleosis include:Person's age with highest risk at 10 to 30 years.Medical history such as close contact with other people with infectious mononucleosis and the presence and time of onset of "mononucleosis-like symptoms" such as fever and sore throat.[citation needed]Physical examination including palpation of any enlarged lymph nodes in the neck or enlarged spleen.The heterophile antibody test is a screening test that gives results within a day but has significantly less than full sensitivity (70–92%) in the first two weeks after clinical symptoms begin.Serological tests take longer time than the heterophile antibody test but are more accurate.
Treatment: Infectious mononucleosis is generally self-limiting so only symptomatic or supportive treatments are used.

Signs_and_symptoms: The onset of symptoms is sudden and initial symptoms are predominately non-specific including fever chills headaches muscle pain or aching a feeling of discomfort loss of appetite lack of energy/fatigue and confusion. These symptoms are usually accompanied by respiratory symptoms such as a dry cough sore or dry throat hoarse voice and a stuffy or runny nose.
Diagnosis: Diagnostic methods that can identify influenza include viral cultures antibody- and antigen-detecting tests and nucleic acid-based tests.
Treatment: Treatment of influenza in cases of mild or moderate illness is supportive and includes anti-fever medications such as acetaminophen and ibuprofen adequate fluid intake to avoid dehydration and resting at home.

Signs_and_symptoms: Infection causes acute non-bloody diarrhea with crampy abdominal pain which can last for weeks and result in malabsorption and weight loss
Diagnosis: Microscopic demonstration of the large typically shaped oocysts is the basis for diagnosis. Because the oocysts may be passed in small amounts and intermittently repeated stool examinations and concentration procedures are recommended. If stool examinations are negative examination of duodenal specimens by biopsy or string test (Enterotest) may be needed. The oocysts can be visualized on wet mounts by microscopy with bright-field differential interference contrast (DIC) and epifluorescence. They can also be stained by modified acid-fast stain.

Signs_and_symptoms: Fever headache and malaise cachexia hemiparesis convulsions and a raised body temperature between 38 to 41 degrees C (100.4 to 105.8 degrees F) Mental retardation
Diagnosis: Available tests detecting JE virus-specific IgM antibodies in serum and/or cerebrospinal fluid for example by IgM capture ELISA.

Signs_and_symptoms: Fever > 5 days large lymph nodes rash sore throat diarrhea
Diagnosis: Based on symptoms ultrasound of the heart

Treatment: Treatment depends on the cause of the keratitis. Infectious keratitis can progress rapidly and generally requires urgent antibacterial antifungal or antiviral therapy to eliminate the pathogen. Antibacterial solutions include levofloxacin gatifloxacin moxifloxacin ofloxacin. It is unclear if steroid eye drops are useful or not

Signs_and_symptoms: Body tremors random outbursts of laughter gradual loss of coordination
Partial or complete temporary or permanent hearing loss
Cough shortness of breath fever muscle pains headaches
Treatment: Effective antibiotics include most macrolides tetracyclines ketolides and quinolones.

Signs_and_symptoms: Skin ulcers fever low red blood cells enlarged liver
Diagnosis: Leishmaniasis is diagnosed in the hematology laboratory by direct visualization of the amastigotes (Leishman–Donovan bodies). Buffy-coat preparations of peripheral blood or aspirates from marrow spleen lymph nodes or skin lesions should be spread on a slide to make a thin smear and stained with Leishman stain or Giemsa stain (pH 7.2) for 20 minutes.
Treatment: For visceral leishmaniasis in India South America and the Mediterranean liposomal amphotericin B is the recommended treatment and is often used as a single dose. Rates of cure with a single dose of amphotericin have been reported as 95%. In India almost all infections are resistant to pentavalent antimonials. In Africa a combination of pentavalent antimonials and paromomycin is recommended. These however can have significant side effects. Miltefosine an oral medication is effective against both visceral and cutaneous leishmaniasis.

Signs_and_symptoms: Numbness small nodules deformation of extremities
Diagnosis: In countries where people are frequently infected a person is considered to have leprosy if they have one of the following two signs:Skin lesion consistent with leprosy and with definite sensory loss.Positive skin smears.
Testing blood for antibodies against the bacterium or its DNA
Culture of blood or spinal fluid

Signs_and_symptoms: Expanding area of redness at the site of a tick bite fever headache tiredness
Diagnosis: Based on symptoms tick exposure blood tests

Signs_and_symptoms: Severe swelling of extremities thickened skin
Fever lack of appetite headache muscle aches malaise nausea and/or vomiting
Headache fever shivering joint pain vomiting hemolytic anemia jaundice hemoglobin in the urine retinal damage and convulsions
Diagnosis: Examination of the blood antigen detection tests

Signs_and_symptoms: Fever cough runny nose red Fever cough runny nose inflamed eyes rash
Diagnosis: Typically clinical diagnosis begins with the onset of fever and malaise about 10 days after exposure to the measles virus followed by the emergence of cough coryza and conjunctivitis that worsen in severity over 4 days of appearing. Observation of Koplik's spots is also diagnostic.
Growing the bacteria in culture mediums

Signs_and_symptoms: Flu-like symptoms stiff neck altered mental status seizures purpura
Treatment: Treatment in primary care usually involves prompt intramuscular administration of benzylpenicillin and then an urgent transfer to hospital (hopefully an academic level I medical center or at least a hospital with round the clock neurological care ideally with neurological intensive and critical care units) for further care. Once in the hospital the antibiotics of choice are usually IV broad spectrum 3rd generation cephalosporins e.g. cefotaxime or ceftriaxone. Benzylpenicillin and chloramphenicol are also effective.

Diagnosis: Metagonimiasis is diagnosed by eggs seen in feces.

Treatment: Fumagillin has been used in the treatment. Another agent used is albendazole.

Signs_and_symptoms: Small raised pink lesions with a dimple in the center
Fever headache muscle pains shivering blistering rash swollen lymph nodes
Parotitis and non-specific symptoms such as fever headache malaise muscle pain and loss of appetite
Diagnosis: Antibody testing viral cultures and reverse transcription polymerase chain reaction

Signs_and_symptoms: Headache fever muscle pain joint pain nausea and vomiting
Diagnosis: Early diagnosis continued to be based on clinical suspicion.
Treatment: The most effective antibiotics include tetracycline and chloramphenicol.

Signs_and_symptoms: Severe coughing fits ending in gasps
